text: The Bishop of Bangor is the ordinary of the Church in Wales Diocese of Bangor. The see is based in the city of Bangor where the bishop's seat (cathedra) is at Cathedral Church of Saint Deiniol. The Report of the Commissioners appointed by his Majesty to inquire into the Ecclesiastical Revenues of England and Wales (1835) found the see had an annual net income of £4,464.The National Cyclopaedia of Useful Knowledge Vol.III, (1847) London, Charles Knight, p.362 This made it the second wealthiest diocese in Wales, after St Asaph. The incumbent is Right Reverend Andrew John, who was consecrated on 29 November 2008 and enthroned on 24 January 2009. The bishop's residence is ("Bishop's House") in Bangor. ==List of Bishops of Bangor== ===Pre-Reformation bishops=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:95%;" border="1" cellpadding="2" |- ! colspan="4" style="background-color: #7F1734; color: white;" | Pre- Reformation Bishops of Bangor |- ! style="background-color: #D4B1BB; width: 10%;" | From ! style="background-color: #D4B1BB; width: 10%;" | Until ! style="background-color: #D4B1BB; width: 30%;" | Incumbent ! style="background-color: #D4B1BB; width: 45%;" | Notes |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | unknown | style="text-align: center;" | unknown | Saint Deiniol | Also known as Daniel; he founded the monastery at Bangor . |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | unknown | style="text-align: center;" | | colspan="2" | Dates and names for this period are not known. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | | style="text-align: center;" | | Elfodd | Also known as Elbodug, Ellodu; described as chief bishop of Venedotia, probably Bishop of Bangor. Possibly identical with Elfodd who was bishop of St David's |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | | style="text-align: center;" | | colspan="2" | Dates and names for this period are not known. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text- align: center;" | | style="text-align: center;" | | Mordaf | Possibly identical with Morlais who was bishop of St David's |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | | style="text-align: center;" | | colspan="2" | Dates and names for this period are not known. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text- align: center;" | | style="text-align: center;" | unknown | Dyfan | |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | | style="text-align: center;" | unknown | Revedun | |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1092 | style="text-align: center;" | 1108 | Hervey le Breton | Also known as Hervæus. Consecrated 1092; forced to flee the diocese in the late 1090s; translated to Ely in 1108. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text- align: center;" | 1109 | style="text-align: center;" | 1120 | colspan="2" | See vacant |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text- align: center;" | 1120 | style="text-align: center;" | 1139 | David the Scot | Consecrated 4 April 1120; probably died in 1139. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1140 | style="text-align: center;" | 1161 | Meurig | Maurice; elected before December 1139 and consecrated in late January 1140; died 12 August 1161. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1163 | style="text-align: center;" | 1169 | Arthur of Bardsey | Possibly nominated before October 1163 by Owain Gwynedd and was probably consecrated in Ireland before 1165; he was not accepted by Thomas Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury and was urged to give up the post in April or May 1169. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1177 | style="text-align: center;" | 1190 | Gwion | Wido or Guy Rufus; consecrated 22 May 1177; died 1190. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | colspan="2" style="text-align: center;" | el. 1193/96 | Rotoland | Subprior of Aberconwy; elected bishop between 1191 and 1196, but nothing further is known. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1195 | style="text-align: center;" | 1196 | Alan | Alban; formerly Prior of St John of Jerusalem; consecrated 16 April 1195; died in May or December 1196. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1197 | style="text-align: center;" | 1213 | Robert of Shrewsbury | Consecrated 16 March 1197; died in 1213. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1215 | style="text-align: center;" | 1236 | Cadwgan of Llandyfai | Martin; elected before 13 April and consecrated 21 June 1215; resigned 1235 or 1236; died 11 April 1241. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" colspan="2" | 1236 | Hywel ap Ednyfed | Elected in 1236, but was never not consecrated. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1236 | style="text-align: center;" | 1267 | Richard | Elected before 3 July 1236 and consecrated in 1237; absent from the diocese from 1248 to 1258; died before 8 November 1267. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1267 | style="text-align: center;" | 1307 | Anion | Anian or Enian; formerly Archdeacon of Anglesey; elected bishop before 12 December 1267; consecrated in 1267 or 1268; received possession of the temporalities 5 January 1268; died before 12 January 1307. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1307 | style="text-align: center;" | 1309 | Gruffydd ap Iorwerth | Consecrated 26 March 1307; died 27 April 1309. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1309 | style="text-align: center;" | 1328 | Einion Sais | Elected between 2 May and 18 June 1309; received possession of the temporalities 7 September and consecrated 9 November 1309; died 26 January 1328. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1328 | style="text-align: center;" | 1357 | Matthew de Englefeld | Madog ap Iowerth; elected 26 February and consecrated 12 June 1328; died between 22 March and 15 April 1357. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text- align: center;" colspan="2" | 1357 | Ithel ap Robert | Elected bishop in 1357, but was quashed by Pope Innocent VI. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1357 | style="text-align: center;" | 1366 | Thomas de Ringstead OP | Appointed 21 August and consecrated after 17 September 1357; died 8 January 1366. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" colspan="2" | 1366 | Alexander Dalby | Nominated by Edward of Woodstock, Prince of Wales; a papal mandate was issued 29 April 1366 to the Archbishop of Bordeaux that he should hold an inquiry and notify the pope within two months whether Dalby understood Welsh well enough to preach in the language; nothing further is heard. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1366 | style="text-align: center;" | 1370 | Gervase de Castro OP | Appointed 11 December 1366; died 24 September or 30 October 1370. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1371 | style="text-align: center;" | 1372 | Hywel ab Goronwy | Appointed 21 April 1371; died before 3 February 1372; the Welsh Poet, Dafydd ap Gwilym wrote a poem of praise to him when he was Dean of Bangor. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1372 | style="text-align: center;" | 1375 | John Gilbert OP | Appointed 17 March and received possession of the temporalities 30 April 1372; translated to Hereford 12 September 1375. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" colspan="2" | 1375/76 | Geoffrey Herdeby OFSA | A petition was sent to the pope for Herdeby to be appointment as bishop, however, Swaffham became bishop instead. |- valign="top" style="background- color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1376 | style="text-align: center;" | 1398 | John Swaffham OCarm | Translated from Cloyne 2 July 1276 and received possession of the temporalities 28 October 1376; died 24 June 1398. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" colspan="2" | 1398 | Lewis Aber | Elected before 21 August 1398, but vacated soon afterwards. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1398 | style="text-align: center;" | 1404 | Richard Young | Appointed 2 December 1398; received possession of the temporalities 20 May 1400; probably consecrated in Rome 1400; absent from the diocese after 1401; translated to Rochester 28 July 1404. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1405 | style="text-align: center;" | 1408 | Lewis Byford | Llywelyn Biford; appointed by Pope Boniface IX; held the diocese from 1405 until ejected by Young's appointment in 1408. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1408 | style="text-align: center;" | 1418 | Griffin Yonge | Gruffydd Young; appointed by Antipope Benedict XIII in 1408, but was declared void and was appointed to Ross by Pope Martin V on 14 February 1418. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text- align: center;" | 1408 | style="text-align: center;" | 1417 | Benedict Nichols | Appointed by Pope Gregory XII 18 April and consecrated 12 August 1408; translated to St David's in December 1417. |- valign="top" style="background- color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1418 | style="text-align: center;" | 1423 | William Barrow | Formerly a Canon of Lincoln; appointed 14 February 1418 and consecrated after 13 October 1419; translated to Carlisle 19 April 1423. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text- align: center;" | 1423 | style="text-align: center;" | 1435 | John Clederowe | John Cliderow; formerly a Canon of Chichester; appointed 19 April 1423 and consecrated in 1425; died before 13 December 1435. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1436 | style="text-align: center;" | 1448 | Thomas Cheriton OP | Appointed 5 March and received possession of the temporalities 21 November 1436; consecrated 25 November 1436; died 23 December 1447. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1448 | style="text-align: center;" | 1453 | John Stanberry OCarm | John Stanbury; appointed 4 March and received possession of the temporalities 15 May 1448; consecrated 23 June 1448; translated to Hereford 7 February 1453. |- valign="top" style="background- color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1453 | style="text-align: center;" | 1464 | James Blakedon OP | Translated from Achonry 7 February and received possession of the temporalities 25 March 1453; died before 3 October 1464. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1464 | style="text-align: center;" | 1494 | Richard Edenham OFM | Richard Edenam; appointed 14 January and consecrated after 18 March 1465; died before 13 April 1494. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1494 | style="text-align: center;" | 1500 | Henry Deane OCanSA | Formerly Prior of Llanthony; appointed 4 July 1494; elected 13 September 1494; consecrated 20 November 1495; appointed again 21 July 1496; received possession of the temporalities 6 October 1496; also was Lord Chancellor of Ireland 1494–1495; translated to Salisbury 8 January 1500 and Canterbury in 1501. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1500 | style="text-align: center;" | 1504 | Thomas Pigot OSB | Appointed 4 May 1500; died 15 August 1504. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1504 | style="text-align: center;" | 1508 | John Penny OCanSA | Appointed 30 August and consecrated in 1505; translated to Carlisle 22 September 1508. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1509 | style="text-align: center;" | 1533 | Thomas Skevington OCist | Thomas Skeffington; formerly Abbot of Waverley; appointed 22 February and consecrated 17 June 1509; died 16 August 1533. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | colspan="4" style="text-align: center;" | Source(s):Hardy, T. Translated from the suffragan see of Penreth, traditionally associated with Penrith; but since he was consecrated for the Diocese of Llandaff this must be a doubtful identification. Elected 24 July and received possession of the temporalities 9 September 1539; translated to Chester 4 August 1541. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1541 | style="text-align: center;" | 1552 | Arthur Bulkeley | Elected 18 November 1541 and consecrated 19 February 1542; died 14 March 1553. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1552 | style="text-align: center;" | 1555 | colspan="2" | See vacant |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1555 | style="text-align: center;" | 1558 | William Glyn | William Glynn or Glynne; consecrated 8 September 1555; died 21 May 1558. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" colspan="2" | 1558 | Maurice Clenock | Maurice Clynnog; first head of the English College, Rome; elected bishop, but was never consecrated, owing to the change of religion under Elizabeth I of England. |- valign="top" style="background- color: #F7F0F2;" | colspan="4" style="text-align: center;" | Source(s):Bishops of Bangor - 1267–1553. consecrated 1 July 1666; died 1 September 1673. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1673 | style="text-align: center;" | 1689 | 60px Humphrey Lloyd | Formerly Dean of St Asaph; consecrated 30 June 1689; translated to Hereford 2 December 1701. |- valign="top" style="background- color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1701 | style="text-align: center;" | 1716 | 60px John Evans | Consecrated 4 January 1702; consecrated in early 1722; translated to Lincoln 17 June 1723. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1723 | style="text-align: center;" | 1727 | 60px William Baker | Formerly Warden of Wadham College, Oxford; consecrated 11 August 1723; translated to Norwich 19 December 1727. |- valign="top" style="background- color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1728 | style="text-align: center;" | 1734 | 60px Thomas Sherlock | Formerly Dean of Chichester; consecrated 4 February 1728; translated to Salisbury 8 November 1734. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1734 | style="text-align: center;" | 1737 | 60px Charles Cecil | Translated from Bristol in late 1734; died 29 May 1737. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1737 | style="text-align: center;" | 1743 | 60px Thomas Herring | Formerly Dean of Rochester; consecrated 15 January 1738; translated to York 21 April 1743 then Canterbury in 1747. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1743 | style="text-align: center;" | 1747 | 60px Matthew Hutton | Consecrated 13 November 1743; translated to York 10 December 1747 then Canterbury in 1757. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1748 | style="text-align: center;" | 1756 | 60px Zachary Pearce | Formerly Dean of Winchester; consecrated 21 February 1748; translated to Rochester 4 June 1756. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1756 | style="text-align: center;" | 1768 | 60px John Egerton | Formerly Dean of Hereford; consecrated 4 July 1756; translated to Lichfield 12 November 1768. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1769 | style="text-align: center;" | 1774 | 60px John Ewer | Translated from Llandaff 10 January 1769; died 28 October 1774. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1774 | style="text-align: center;" | 1783 | 60px John Moore | Formerly Dean of Canterbury; consecrated 12 February 1775; translated to Canterbury 26 April 1783. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1783 | style="text-align: center;" | 1800 | 60px John Warren | Translated from St David's 9 June 1783; died 27 January 1800. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1800 | style="text-align: center;" | 1806 | 60px William Cleaver | Translated from Chester 24 May 1800; then translated to St Asaph after 24 October 1806. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1807 | style="text-align: center;" | 1809 | 60px John Randolph | Translated from Oxford 6 January 1807; then translated to London 9 August 1809. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1809 | style="text-align: center;" | 1830 | 60px Henry Majendie | Translated from Chester 5 October 1809; died 9 July 1830. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1830 | style="text-align: center;" | 1859 | 60px Christopher Bethell | Translated from Exeter 28 October 1830; died 19 April 1859. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1859 | style="text-align: center;" | 1890 | 60px James Colquhoun Campbell | Formerly Archdeacon of Llandaff; consecrated 14 June 1859; resigned in April 1890; died 9 November 1895. |- valign="top" style="background-color: #F7F0F2;" | style="text-align: center;" | 1890 | style="text-align: center;" | 1898 | 60px Daniel Lewis Lloyd | Formerly Headmaster of Friars School, Bangor and Christ College, Brecon; consecrated 24 June 1890; resigned in November 1898; died 4 August 1899. |- valign="top" style="background-color: white;" | style="text- align: center;" | 1899 | style="text-align: center;" | 1920 | 60px Watkin Williams | Consecrated 2 February 1899. |} ====Bishops of the disestablished Church in Wales==== {| class="wikitable" style="width:95%;" border="1" cellpadding="2" |- ! colspan="4" style="background-color: #7F1734; title: Bishop of Bangor
